study_scale: 1 site in monitoring network inner-alpine Swiss Rhone valley
big_problems: This study measured gsl, but only to look at the effect on growth of exogenous factors (soil moisture). It's not really looking at GSLxGrowth relationships
missing_something_major: I think they have to dat to start looking at GSLXgrowth too, but not sure why they didn’t

study_scale: 1 site in monitoring network inner-alpine Swiss Rhone valley
3 sites along elevational gradient and 80 individuals
study_level: merged individuals across sites, I think
excellent_study: They didn’t explicitly look at GSL, but they did use snow melt out and snow free growing degree days as a proxy. If we believe this is a good proxy for start of growing season for this shrub then the paper was good and looked at variation in response to cliamte across elevations too. I just wish they had explicitly also looked at leaf phenology to describe growing season onset

study_scale: 3 sites along elevational gradient and 80 individuals
study_level: merged individuals across sites, I think
big_problems: no, other than how weird tree ring methods are
missing_something_major: cannot figure end date of GDD calc

study_scale: 15 sites in Slovenia and 153 tree chronologies
big_problems: I don't fully understand why they detrended the phenology data

excellent_study: maybe! They did the comparison very directly but see my concerns ….
big_problems: not clear how the got the phenology data to match the tree core data

study_scale: 10 elevational bands in 3 elevational transects on mountains in the eastern Swiss Alps
growth_metric: stem density; proportion flowering; proportion fruiting
ifyouthink_no_why: they used snowmelt as a proxy for GSL but didn't actually measure or use the full GSL. I think it's more evidence for start of growing season and growth relationship
missing_something_major: they had vegetation phenolgy data but didn’t use it as a predictor, only as a response variable. Seems like they potentially have the data to look at stem density (their proxy fro biomass) ~ length of vegetative growing season
notes: 1. they used stem density as their measure of biomass; 2. they used elevation as a proxy for growing season temperature

study_scale: 10 elevational bands in 3 elevational transects on mountains in the eastern Swiss Alps
growth_metric: stem density; proportion flowering; proportion fruiting
ifyouthink_no_why: they don't directly measure it and their growth metrics are not super appropriate for our question
excellent_study: no, but I appreciated their ecological slant
big_problems: for us -- they are too focused on snowmelt and fitness-related stuff
notes: space for time study (they even merged data across years)

ifyes_whichexternal: spring temperature mainly, but also elevation, precipication (they also looked at land cover and other climate variables)
big_problems: The study didn't really look at direct metrics of growth or growing season so not really. They didn't explicitly look at growing season length but did examine spring temp and productivty. I though it was cool that they looked at productivity in spring but also in summer and fall separatelt and were able to find lags that were somewhat explained by elevation and precipiation
